String Operations

　In TJS2, strings are pseudo-objects of the String class, but the String class does not actually exist, and they are not truly objects of a String class (however, using the typeof operator on a string will return "String").
　However, by treating a string as an object, several methods and properties become available.

length

　The length property returns the length of the string. Please note that it is a property, not a method. However, you cannot assign a value to this property.

　Since TJS internally handles all characters in UNICODE, both full-width and half-width characters are counted as 1 character.

Example:
    var str = "abc漢字";
    var n = str.length;  // 5 is assigned to n
    var n = "abc漢字".length; // Similarly, 5 is assigned here

'Numeric' Property

　By indirectly specifying a numeric value as a property, you can access the character at that position.
　For example, if str is a string or an expression representing a string, str[0] will be a string representing the first character.
　An exception occurs if the number is beyond the string length or negative (however, an empty string is returned for the position after the last character of the string).

　Assignment expressions cannot be created.

Example:
    var str = "abcdef";
    var c = str[0];  // 'a' is assigned to c
    var c = str[2];  // 'c' is assigned to c
    str[3] = 'A'; // Error because an assignment expression cannot be created
    var c = str[100]; // Error because the index is out of range
    var c = str[6]; // Empty string '' is assigned

charAt

　The charAt method returns the character at the specified position in the string. It behaves similarly to the 'numeric' property, but it always returns an empty string if the index is out of range (it does not throw an exception).

Syntax : charAt(<character position>)

Example:
    var str = "abcdef";     var c = str.charAt(3); // 'd' is assigned to c

indexOf

　The indexOf method returns the position of a substring.

Syntax : indexOf(<substring>[,<start search position>])
　Searches for <substring> in the string starting from <start search position> and returns the position of its first occurrence. Returning 0 indicates the beginning of the string. Returning -1 means it was not found. If <start search position> is omitted, the search starts from the beginning of the string.


Example:
    var str = "abcdefghijkl";
    var n = str.indexOf("fgh"); // 5 is assigned to n
    var n = str.indexOf("xyz"); // -1 is assigned to n

toLowerCase

　This method takes no arguments.
　toLowerCase returns a string with all alphabetic characters converted to lowercase.
　Full-width characters are not converted.

　These methods do not affect the original string.

Example:
    var lwr="ABCDEF".toLowerCase(); // "abcdef" is assigned to lwr

Note
　In the current version of TJS2, conversion is performed only for characters with character codes less than 0x80.

toUpperCase

　This method is the opposite of toLowerCase; it returns a string with lowercase alphabetic characters converted to uppercase.

substring

　The substring method returns a substring of the string.

Syntax : substring(<start character position>[,<number of characters>])
　Returns a substring of <number of characters> starting from <start character position>. It does not affect the original string. If <number of characters> is omitted, all characters from <start character position> to the end are returned.
　Please note that the meanings of the arguments differ from the equivalent method in JavaScript.

Example:
    var ss="abcdefghijkl".substring(3,3); // "def" is assigned to ss

substr

　Same as substring.

sprintf

　The sprintf method formats a string.

Syntax : sprintf(argument, argument, ....)
　Treats the string as a format string and returns a string formatted similarly to the sprintf function in C. It does not affect the original string.

Example:
    var formatted = "%04X %c %5d".sprintf(v1, v2, dic[v1]);

replace

　The replace method performs string replacement.

Syntax : replace(<pattern>, <replacement string>)
　Replaces occurrences according to a regular expression pattern and returns the resulting string. It does not affect the original string.
　Regarding its behavior, please refer to the replace method of the RegExp class.

split

　The split method splits a string.

Syntax : split(<pattern/delimiter set>, <(reserved)>, <ignore empty elements=false>)
　Returns an array object containing the results of splitting the string.

　See also the split method of the Array class (note the order of the arguments).

escape

　The escape method converts a string into a format that can be represented as a TJS string literal. Symbols such as \ or " are all escaped using the \ symbol so they are not interpreted as special characters.

Syntax : escape()
　Returns the escaped string. It does not affect the original string.


Example:
    var escaped = str.escape(); // e.g., " in str becomes \", and \ becomes \\ 

trim

　The trim method returns a string with whitespace removed from the beginning and end. It does not affect the original string.
　Whitespace at the beginning and end refers to characters with character codes U+0001 to U+0020. That is, it includes ASCII control characters and such, but does not include so-called full-width spaces.
　If there are consecutive instances of such whitespace at the beginning or end, they are all removed.

Syntax : trim()
　Returns a string with leading and trailing whitespace removed. It does not affect the original string.


Example:
    var str = "  Hoge ".trim(); // str is "Hoge".

reverse

　The reverse method returns a string with the sequence of characters reversed. It does not affect the original string.
　In the current version of TJS2, the behavior for strings containing UTF-16 surrogate pairs is not guaranteed.

Syntax : reverse()
　Returns a string with the sequence of characters reversed. It does not affect the original string.


Example:
    var str = "Hoge".reverse(); // str is "egoH".

repeat

　The repeat method returns a string that repeats the original string a specified number of times. It does not affect the original string.

Syntax : repeat(count)
　Returns a string repeating this string count times. It does not affect the original string.


Example:
    var str = "Hoge".repeat(3); // str is "HogeHogeHoge".
